subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] how to spell words with /tS/
msgSnippet: ... They should indeed.  tS and dZ are the IPA way of writing ch and j , and there is no effective difference between the one and the other. -- Her he asked
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> I am editing a large word base right now, generated from getting
> phonetical pronunciations from words, and I keep coming across words
> like "branch" and "beach" which my program has transliterated,
> according to the pronunciations, as /<font face="Thoth Sampa">bratS</font>/
> and /<font face="Thoth Sampa">bits</font>/. This seems wrong. It seems
> they should be spelled /<font face="Thoth Sampa">brac</font>/ and /<font
> face="Thoth Sampa">bitc</font>/.<br>

They should indeed. tS and dZ are the IPA way of writing "ch" and "j",
and there is no effective difference between the one and the other.

--
Her he asked if O'Hare Doctor tidings sent from far John Cowan
coast and she with grameful sigh him answered that http://ccil.org/~cowan
O'Hare Doctor in heaven was. Sad was the man that word cowan@...
to hear that him so heavied in bowels ruthful. All
she there told him, ruing death for friend so young, James Joyce, Ulysses
algate sore unwilling God's rightwiseness to withsay. "Oxen of the Sun"

They should indeed.  tS and dZ are the IPA way of writing "ch" and "j",
